content:
衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
TAXONOMIC AND NOMENCL TURAL TTERS
As mentioned on page 5, rules for the taxonomy and nomenclature of the Enterobacteriacease are formulated by the IAMS through its appropriate Committee ad Sub-committee. The International Centres supported by WHO do not themselves exercise such functions. It is, however, obvious that the Centres' usefulness and efficiency are intimately dependent on the existence of a sound and serviceable taxonomic and nomenclatural Tromework, and this is therefore a matter of concern equally to Ho and to the Centres. It is for example necessary to know exactly which bucterial groups are to be included in, and which excluded from, the salmonellae and the shigellae respectively. Accordingly the Consultant Group felt that they should examine some of these taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. For their consideration of these aspects they invited the opinions of several authorities in this field of work, including Dr. S. T. Cowan, permanent Secretary for Medical and Veterinary Bacteriology of the IAMS's International Committee on Bacteriological Nomenclature. A summary of this part of their proceedings is being communicated to the Lis.
SUMMARY
The World Health Organization provides aid to three International Centres for studies on enteric bacteria. These are (1) the International Salmonella and Escherichia Centre, Copenhagen, Denmark, (2) the International Shigella Centre, Atlanta, USA, and (3) the Internetional Shigella Centre, London, England.
In September 1955 the Directors of these three Centres, together with a representative of the International Association of Microbiological Societies, met in order to review the Centres' purposes and functions, and to advise on the further development and co-ordination of their activities.
A brief account is given of the historical origins of the International Centres und of their relationships with WHO.
The basic purposes of the International Centres may be regarded, in the main, as twofold: (a) taxonomic, to promote uniformity and consistency throughout the world in the identification of the micor-organisms concerned, and (b) epidemiological, to fuollitute epidemiological understanding and public health action.
66
Academia Historic,
2
- 21 -
